sample.title: Inside Europe‚Äôs Economic Crises With Christine Lagarde | Leaders with Francine Lacqua
sample.description:
Francine Lacqua speaks to Christine Lagarde about Europe‚Äôs economic travails, populism and how to lead through turbulent times. Lagarde, who served as managing director of the International Monetary Fund before becoming president of the European Central Bank, reflects on her response to the global financial crisis, the Eurozone debt crisis and bailout talks with Greece. 

In a widely varied career, she spent more than two decades practicing corporate law before being recruited as France's trade minister in 2005. She sits down with Lacqua in Frankfurt to reveal how she handles high-pressure situations, complex negotiations and dramatic change.

sample.title: Why One Oil Company Has a Head Start in Venezuela
sample.description:
With President Nicol√°s Maduro deposed, President Donald Trump wants US oil giants to revive Venezuela‚Äôs energy industry. Though it‚Äôs unclear who, if anyone, will take part in his plan, Chevron is already there.

After the US attack on the South American country and its rendition of President Nicol√°s Maduro, Trump said he wants to rebuild the country‚Äôs beleaguered infrastructure. While the oil majors mull his entreaties, Chevron may have a distinct advantage since it‚Äôs been operating in Venezuela for decades.

sample.title: How Weight Loss Pills Could Reshape The GLP-1 Landscape
sample.description:
Injectable GLP-1s for obesity have been revolutionary products of the pharmaceutical industry over the past few years. Now, for the first time, the weight loss drug is being offered in pill form. Novo Nordisk‚Äôs Wegovy pill hit the market on January 5th and rival Eli Lilly has its own version currently waiting for FDA approval. Watch the video to learn why drug companies are racing to get obesity pills onto the market.

Produced, Shot and Edited by: Ryan Baker
Reporter: Annika Kim Constantino
Animation by: Emily Park
Senior Managing Producer: Tala Hadavi

sample.title: How Close Are We To Robots That Actually Do Chores?
sample.description:
Humanoid robots seem to be going mainstream, appearing on stage with Elon Musk, Jensen Huang and all over CES 2026. But in reality, humanoids are often still tele-operated by humans. And they‚Äôre far from ready for mass deployment in the home, where unpredictabilities like kids and pets also raise the stakes for privacy and safety concerns. Still, companies like 1X in the U.S. and Unitree in China are now selling AI home robots for $20,000 and up. CNBC went to the 2nd annual Humanoid Summit in California and CES to find out if home robots will be stuck in demo mode for years to come.

Chapters:
00:00 Introduction
1:29 Hype vs. reality
5:38 Stuck in demo mode
8:33 China and early adoption

sample.title: Anthropic Vs. OpenAI: How Safety Became The Advantage In AI
sample.description:
Daniela and Dario Amodei left OpenAI five years ago to form Anthropic, a company focused on AI safety and enterprise. Since then, the Claude creator's revenue has grown 10x annually for three straight years, with 85% coming from business customers ‚Äî the inverse of OpenAI's consumer-heavy model. Daniela Amodei, the company's president and co-founder, has emerged as the operational counterweight to her brother Dario's technical vision. CNBC's MacKenzie Sigalos interviews Daniela and other experts, and breaks down how Anthropic quietly rose to the top of the AI race.

Chapters:
00:00 Introduction
2:03 The beginning
4:52 The enterprise bet
9:39 Compute is destiny
13:20 An identity defined by OpenAI
16:18 What could go wrong

sample.description:
Division over the federal investigation of the Federal Reserve has rattled the Republican Party. CNBC‚Äôs Eamon Javers reports from Washington, DC, and former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy discusses the probe and the President‚Äôs power at home and abroad. Tune into CNBC tonight for ‚ÄúWarren Buffett: A Life and Legacy,‚Äù a two-hour special of exclusive, never-before-seen interviews with Warren Buffett about his views on business, philanthropy, and life, and how his philosophies have evolved over the decades. Hosted by CNBC‚Äôs Becky Quick, the program will also feature interviews with Warren Buffett‚Äôs three kids ‚Äì Susie, Howie, and Peter ‚Äì who reflect on the enormous responsibility their father has entrusted to them ‚Äì to eventually donate his entire fortune.

sample.title: 'Help is on the way,' Donald Trump says as he urges Iranians to 'keep protesting' | BBC News
sample.description:
US President Donald Trump has urged Iranian anti-government protesters to "keep protesting", saying ‚Äúhelp is on its way‚Äù.
 
"I have cancelled all meetings with Iranian Officials until the senseless killing of protesters stops,‚Äù the president wrote on social media platform Truth Social.
 
Trump has recently floated the possibility of intervention in the country - his national security team is expected to meet today to discuss the options.
 
Thousands of people are feared dead after a crackdown on weeks of anti-government protests in Iran.

sample.title: Venezuela: What happened and what's next? | BBC News
sample.description:
On 3 January, US forces seized Venezuela‚Äôs then president, Nicol√°s Maduro, in a dramatic overnight raid on the capital, Caracas. 

BBC correspondents Ione Wells and Will Grant join Mimi Swaby to look at what happened and what it means for Venezuela now.

sample.title: Russian strikes on Ukraine kill four and leave people with no power | BBC News
sample.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said several hundred thousand people in and around Kyiv are without power today after another Russian missile strike.
 
Parts of the capital are being without heating and electricity for several days now and in sub-zero temperatures.
 
Four people were reportedly killed overnight in Kharkiv and a former power plant in Kyiv was also badly damaged. The Ukrainian military said almost 300 drones and 18 missiles targeted cities across the country.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Ukraine #Russia #BBCNews

sample.title: Minnesota sues Trump administration to block ICE agents deployment | BBC News
sample.description:
The US state of Minnesota has sued the Trump administration in an attempt to block a surge of federal immigration agents into the state.
 
The lawsuit argues the deployment amounts to an unconstitutional "federal invasion". Minnesota's Attorney General Keith Ellison said immigration operations had upended life for millions and caused "chaos and violence".
 
It comes after Renee Good, 37, was shot dead by an immigration agent in Minneapolis last week, triggering large protests in the city.
 
The Trump administration has described the legal action as "baseless". It has also pledged to significantly increase its deployment in the area.
 
Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
 
For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news
 
#Minnesota #US #BBCNews
